social_lstm.utils package¶

Submodules¶

social_lstm.utils.generator module¶

social_lstm.utils.grid module¶

social_lstm.utils.grid.getGridMask(frame, dimensions, num_person, neighborhood_size, grid_size, is_occupancy=False)¶

Computes binary occupancy masks for each pedestrian’s neighborhood.

social_lstm.utils.grid.getSequenceGridMask(sequence, dimensions, pedlist_seq, neighborhood_size, grid_size, using_cuda, is_occupancy=False)¶

Get the grid masks for all the frames in the sequence params: sequence : A numpy matrix of shape SL x MNP x 3 dimensions : This will be a list [width, height] neighborhood_size : Scalar value representing the size of neighborhood considered grid_size : Scalar value representing the size of the grid discretization using_cuda: Boolean value denoting if using GPU or not is_occupancy: A flag using for calculation of accupancy map

social_lstm.utils.helper module¶

social_lstm.utils.helper.Gaussian2DLikelihood(outputs, targets, nodesPresent, look_up)¶

params: outputs : predicted locations targets : true locations assumedNodesPresent : Nodes assumed to be present in each frame in the sequence nodesPresent : True nodes present in each frame in the sequence look_up : lookup table for determining which ped is in which array index

social_lstm.utils.helper.Gaussian2DLikelihoodInference(outputs, targets, nodesPresent, pred_length, look_up)¶

Computes the likelihood of predicted locations under a bivariate Gaussian distribution at test time

Parameters:

outputs: Torch variable containing tensor of shape seq_length x numNodes x 1 x output_size targets: Torch variable containing tensor of shape seq_length x numNodes x 1 x input_size nodesPresent : A list of lists, of size seq_length. Each list contains the nodeIDs that are present in the frame

social_lstm.utils.helper.get_all_file_names(path)¶
social_lstm.utils.helper.get_args()¶

Returns the parsed arguments.

Parameters: - input_size (int): size of input data (default: 2) - output_size (int): size of output data (default: 5) - rnn_size (int): size of RNNs (default: 128) - embedding_size (int): size of embedding layer (default: 64) - grid_size (int): size of grid (default: 4) - maxNumPeds (int): maximum number of pedestrians in a frame (default: 27) - dropout (float): dropout rate for RNNs (default: 0.5) - use_cuda (bool): whether to use CUDA or not (default: True if available) - obs_length (int): observed length of the trajectory (default: 8) - pred_length (int): predicted length of the trajectory (default: 12) - epoch (int): epoch of the model to be loaded (default: 24) - gru (bool): whether to use GRU cell or LSTM cell (default: False) - method (int): type of LSTM method (default: 1)

1: social LSTM 2: obstacle LSTM 3: vanilla LSTM

Returns:

parsed arguments

Return type:

args (argparse.Namespace)

social_lstm.utils.helper.get_final_error(ret_nodes, nodes, assumedNodesPresent, trueNodesPresent, look_up)¶
Parameters:

  • ret_nodes (A tensor of shape pred_length x numNodes x 2)

  • nodes (Contains the true positions for the)

  • nodes

  • nodes

  • lists (nodesPresent)

  • time-step (Each list contains the nodeIDs of the nodes present at that)

  • look_up (lookup table for determining which ped is in which array index)

Returns:

  • Error (Mean final euclidean distance between predicted trajectory and the true trajectory)

social_lstm.utils.helper.get_method_name(index)¶

Returns the method name given the index.

Parameters: index (int) : Index of the method (1 = Social LSTM, 2 = Obstacle LSTM, 3 = Vanilla LSTM)

Returns: str : Method name

social_lstm.utils.helper.get_model(index, arguments, infer=False)¶

Returns a model given the index and arguments.

Parameters: index (int) : Index of the model (1 = Social LSTM, 2 = Obstacle LSTM, 3 = Vanilla LSTM) arguments (dict) : Arguments to pass to the model infer (bool, optional) : Whether to use the model for inference or training. Defaults to False.

Returns: nn.Module : The model

social_lstm.utils.helper.remove_file_extention(file_name)¶
social_lstm.utils.helper.revert_seq(x_seq, PedsList_seq, lookup_seq, first_values_dict)¶

Converts a sequence of velocity tensors to absolute position tensors.

Parameters: - x_seq: Tensor of shape (seq_len, num_peds, 2), velocity vectors - PedsList_seq: List of pedestrian ID lists per frame - lookup_seq: Dictionary mapping ped IDs to indices in the tensor - first_values_dict: Dictionary of initial absolute positions per ped ID

Returns: - absolute_x_seq: Tensor of same shape as x_seq with absolute positions

social_lstm.utils.helper.rotate(origin, point, angle)¶

Rotate a point counterclockwise by a given angle around a given origin.

The angle should be given in radians.

social_lstm.utils.helper.rotate_traj_with_target_ped(x_seq, angle, PedsList_seq, lookup_seq)¶
social_lstm.utils.helper.sample_gaussian_2d(mux, muy, sx, sy, corr, nodesPresent, look_up)¶

Sample from a 2D Gaussian for each node.

Parameters:

  • mux (tensors of shape (1, numNodes)) – Mean and std values for each node.

  • muy (tensors of shape (1, numNodes)) – Mean and std values for each node.

  • sx (tensors of shape (1, numNodes)) – Mean and std values for each node.

  • sy (tensors of shape (1, numNodes)) – Mean and std values for each node.

  • corr (tensors of shape (1, numNodes)) – Mean and std values for each node.

  • nodesPresent (list) – List of node IDs present in this frame.

  • look_up (dict) – Maps node IDs to array indices.

Returns:

next_x, next_y – Sampled x and y values.

Return type:

tensors of shape (numNodes,)

social_lstm.utils.path_prediction module¶

social_lstm.utils.path_prediction.prediction_step(ped_data, frame)¶

Make predictions for all pedestrians in the current frame.

Parameters: ped_data (list of [id, x, y]): A list of pedestrian observations. frame (numpy array): The current frame.

Returns: list of (id, predicted_array): A list of tuples containing the id of each pedestrian and an array of their predicted coordinates.

social_lstm.utils.pixel_to_3dpoint module¶

social_lstm.utils.pixel_to_3dpoint.pixel_to_3dpoint(u=None, v=None, depth=None, intr=None, depth_frame=None)¶

Calculates the 3D point corresponding to a given pixel coordinate (u, v) in a depth frame.

Parameters:

  • u (int)

  • v (int)

  • depth (float, optional) – Depth value at the given pixel coordinate. Must be given if depth_frame is None.

  • intr (rs.intrinsics, optional) – Intrinsics of the depth frame. Must be given if depth_frame is None.

  • depth_frame (rs.depth_frame, optional) – Depth frame containing the depth value at the given pixel coordinate.

Returns:

point – 3D point [X, Y, Z] corresponding to the given pixel coordinate.

Return type:

numpy.array

Raises:

ValueError – If neither depth+intr nor depth_frame is given, or if the pixel coordinates (u, v) are None.

social_lstm.utils.pixel_to_3dpoint.pixel_to_3dpoint_median(u=None, v=None, intr=None, depth_frame=None, h=None, w=None, r=None)¶

Calculates the 3D point corresponding to a given pixel coordinate (u, v) in a depth frame by taking the median of all depth values within a specified radius (r) around the pixel coordinate.

Parameters:

  • u (int)

  • v (int) – Pixel coordinates.

  • intr (rs.intrinsics, optional) – Intrinsics of the depth frame. Must be given if depth_frame is None.

  • depth_frame (rs.depth_frame, optional) – Depth frame containing the depth value at the given pixel coordinate. Must be given if depth is None.

  • h (int, optional) – Height of the depth frame. Must be given if depth_frame is None.

  • w (int, optional) – Width of the depth frame. Must be given if depth_frame is None.

  • r (int, optional) – Radius around the pixel coordinate to take the median depth value.

Returns:

point – 3D point [X, Y, Z] corresponding to the given pixel coordinate.

Return type:

numpy.array

Raises:

ValueError – If neither depth+intr nor depth_frame is given, or if the pixel coordinates (u, v) are None.

social_lstm.utils.rtSequenceBuffer module¶

class social_lstm.utils.rtSequenceBuffer.RealTimeSequenceBuffer(seq_length, observation_length)¶

Bases: object

convert_x_seq_format(x_seq_str_arrays)¶

Convert a sequence of string arrays to a sequence of float arrays.

Parameters: x_seq_str_arrays (list of list of str): A sequence of string arrays.

Returns: list of numpy.ndarray: A sequence of float arrays.

get_sequence()¶

Get the sequence of observations.

Returns:

A sequence of observations, where each frame is a numpy array of shape (num_peds, 3). pedsList_seq (list of list of int): A sequence of pedestrian IDs per frame. current_ids (list of int): A list of pedestrian IDs in the current frame.

Return type:

x_seq (list of numpy.ndarray)

Notes

The sequence buffer will be cleared after calling this function.

is_ready()¶

Check if the sequence buffer is ready for inference.

Returns: bool: True if the sequence buffer is ready, False otherwise.

update(id_xy_list)¶

Update the sequence buffer with new observations.

Parameters: id_xy_list (list of [id, x, y]): A list of observations.

Returns: None

social_lstm.utils.shm_writer module¶

class social_lstm.utils.shm_writer.ShmPredictionWriter(name='predictions_shm', max_targets=10, max_points_per_target=15)¶

Bases: object

Writes 3D prediction results to shared memory in a compact binary struct format.

Correct layout (matching ROS reader):

int32 num_targets For each target:

int32 person_id int32 num_points repeated (float32 x, float32 y, float32 z)

close()¶
unlink()¶
write(predictions, timestamp)¶
predictions must be a list of dicts:
{

“target_id”: int, “points”: [(x,y,z), …]

}
